Lec20

\section{Quantum Statistical Mechanics}

There are limitations to the applicability of classical statistical mechanics. The need to include quantum mechanical effects becomes specially apparent at low temperatures. In this section we shall first demonstrate the failure of the classical results in the contexts of heat capacities of molecular gases and solids, and the ultra-violet catastrophe in black body radiation. We shall then reformulate statistical mechanics using quantum concepts.

\section{VI.A Dilute Polyatomic Gases}

Consider a dilute gas of polyatomic molecules. The Hamiltonian for each molecule of nnn atoms is

H1=∑i=1np⃗i22m+V(q⃗1,…,q⃗n)\mathcal{H}_{1}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\vec{p}_{i}^{2}}{2 m}+\mathcal{V}\left(\vec{q}_{1}, \ldots, \vec{q}_{n}\right)H1​=i=1∑n​2mp​i2​​+V(q​1​,…,q​n​)

where the potential energy V\mathcal{V}V, contains all the information on molecular bonds. For simplicity, we have assumed that all atoms in the molecule have the same mass. If the masses are different, the Hamiltonian can be brought into the above form by rescaling the coordinates q⃗i\vec{q}_{i}q​i​ by mi/m\sqrt{m_{i} / m}mi​/m​ (and the momenta by m/mi)\left.\sqrt{m / m_{i}}\right)m/mi​​), where mim_{i}mi​ is the mass of the ith i^{\text {th }}ith  atom. Ignoring the interactions between molecules, the partition function of a dilute gas is

Z(N)=Z1NN!=1N!{∫∏i=1nd3p⃗id3q⃗ih3exp⁡[−β∑i=1np⃗i22m−βV(q⃗1,…,q⃗n)]}NZ(N)=\frac{Z_{1}^{N}}{N !}=\frac{1}{N !}\left\{\int \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{d^{3} \vec{p}_{i} d^{3} \vec{q}_{i}}{h^{3}} \exp \left[-\beta \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\vec{p}_{i}^{2}}{2 m}-\beta \mathcal{V}\left(\vec{q}_{1}, \ldots, \vec{q}_{n}\right)\right]\right\}^{N}Z(N)=N!Z1N​​=N!1​{∫i=1∏n​h3d3p​i​d3q​i​​exp[−βi=1∑n​2mp​i2​​−βV(q​1​,…,q​n​)]}N

The chemical bonds that keep the molecule together are usually quite strong (energies of the order of electron volts). At typical accessible temperatures, which are much smaller than the corresponding dissociation temperatures (≈104∘K)\left(\approx 10^{4 \circ} \mathrm{K}\right)(≈104∘K), the molecule has a well defined shape and only undergoes small deformations. The contribution of these deformations to the one particle partition function Z1Z_{1}Z1​, can be computed as follows:

(a) The first step is to find the equilibrium positions, (q⃗1∗,…,q⃗n∗)\left(\vec{q}_{1}^{*}, \ldots, \vec{q}_{n}^{*}\right)(q​1∗​,…,q​n∗​), by minimizing the potential V\mathcal{V}V.

(b) The energy cost of small deformations about equilibrium is then obtained by setting q⃗i=q⃗i∗+u⃗i\vec{q}_{i}=\vec{q}_{i}^{*}+\vec{u}_{i}q​i​=q​i∗​+ui​, and making an expansion in powers of u⃗\vec{u}u

V=V∗+12∑i,j=1n∑α,β=13∂2V∂qi,α∂qj,βui,αuj,β+O(u3)\mathcal{V}=\mathcal{V}^{*}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i, j=1}^{n} \sum_{\alpha, \beta=1}^{3} \frac{\partial^{2} \mathcal{V}}{\partial q_{i, \alpha} \partial q_{j, \beta}} u_{i, \alpha} u_{j, \beta}+\mathcal{O}\left(u^{3}\right)V=V∗+21​i,j=1∑n​α,β=1∑3​∂qi,α​∂qj,β​∂2V​ui,α​uj,β​+O(u3)

(Here i,j=1,⋯ ,ni, j=1, \cdots, ni,j=1,⋯,n, identify the atoms, and α,β=1,2,3\alpha, \beta=1,2,3α,β=1,2,3 label a particular component.) Since the expansion is around a stable equilibrium configuration, the first derivatives are absent in eq.(VI.3), and the matrix of second derivatives is positive definite, i.e. it has only non-negative eigenvalues.

(c) The normal modes of the molecule are obtained by diagonalizing the 3n×3n3 n \times 3 n3n×3n matrix ∂2V/∂qi,α∂qj,β.\partial^{2} \mathcal{V} / \partial q_{i, \alpha} \partial q_{j, \beta} .∂2V/∂qi,α​∂qj,β​. The resulting 3n3 n3n eigenvalues KsK_{s}Ks​, indicate the stiffness of each mode. We can change variables from the original deformations {u⃗i}\left\{\vec{u}_{i}\right\}{ui​}, to the amplitudes {u~s}\left\{\tilde{u}_{s}\right\}{u~s​}, of the eigenmodes. The corresponding conjugate momenta are p~s=mu~˙s.\tilde{p}_{s}=m \dot{\tilde{u}}_{s} .p~​s​=mu~˙s​. Since the transformation from {u⃗i}\left\{\vec{u}_{i}\right\}{ui​} to {u~s}\left\{\tilde{u}_{s}\right\}{u~s​} is unitary (preserving the length of a vector), ∑ip⃗i2=∑sp~s2\sum_{i} \vec{p}_{i}{ }^{2}=\sum_{s} \tilde{p}_{s}^{2}∑i​p​i​2=∑s​p~​s2​, and the quadratic part of the resulting deformation Hamiltonian is

H1=V∗+∑s=13n[12mp~s2+Ks2u~s2]\mathcal{H}_{1}=\mathcal{V}^{*}+\sum_{s=1}^{3 n}\left[\frac{1}{2 m} \tilde{p}_{s}^{2}+\frac{K_{s}}{2} \tilde{u}_{s}^{2}\right]H1​=V∗+s=1∑3n​[2m1​p~​s2​+2Ks​​u~s2​]

(Such transformations are also canonical, preserving the measure of integration in phase space, ∏i,αdui,αdpi,α=∏sdu~sdp~s.)\left.\prod_{i, \alpha} d u_{i, \alpha} d p_{i, \alpha}=\prod_{s} d \tilde{u}_{s} d \tilde{p}_{s} .\right)∏i,α​dui,α​dpi,α​=∏s​du~s​dp~​s​.)

The average energy of each molecule is the expectation value of the above Hamiltonian. Since each quadratic degree of freedom classically contributes a factor of kBT/2k_{B} T / 2kB​T/2 to the energy,

⟨H1⟩=V∗+3n+m2kBT\left\langle\mathcal{H}_{1}\right\rangle=\mathcal{V}^{*}+\frac{3 n+m}{2} k_{B} T⟨H1​⟩=V∗+23n+m​kB​T

Only modes with a finite stiffness can store potential energy, and mmm is defined as the number such modes with non-zero Ks.K_{s} .Ks​. The following symmetries of the potential force some eigenvalues to zero:

(a) Translation symmetry: Since V(q1→+c⃗,⋯ ,q⃗n+c⃗)=V(q⃗1,⋯ ,q⃗n)\mathcal{V}\left(\overrightarrow{q_{1}}+\vec{c}, \cdots, \vec{q}_{n}+\vec{c}\right)=\mathcal{V}\left(\vec{q}_{1}, \cdots, \vec{q}_{n}\right)V(q1​​+c,⋯,q​n​+c)=V(q​1​,⋯,q​n​), no energy is stored the center of mass coordinate Q⃗=∑αq⃗α/n\vec{Q}=\sum_{\alpha} \vec{q}_{\alpha} / nQ​=∑α​q​α​/n, i.e. V(Q⃗)=V(Q⃗+c⃗)\mathcal{V}(\vec{Q})=\mathcal{V}(\vec{Q}+\vec{c})V(Q​)=V(Q​+c), and the corresponding three values of Ktrans K_{\text {trans }}Ktrans ​ are zero.

(b) Rotation symmetry: There is also no potential energy associated with rotations of the molecule, and Krot=0K_{\mathrm{rot}}=0Krot​=0 for the corresponding stiffnesses. The number of rotational modes, 0≤r≤30 \leq r \leq 30≤r≤3, depends on the shape of the molecule; for example, a rod shaped molecule has r=2r=2r=2, as a rotation parallel to its axis does not result in a new configuration.

The remaining m=3n−3−rm=3 n-3-rm=3n−3−r eigenvectors of the matrix have non-zero stiffness, and correspond to the vibrational normal modes. The energy per molecule, from eq.(VI.5), is thus

⟨H1⟩=6n−3−r2kBT\left\langle\mathcal{H}_{1}\right\rangle=\frac{6 n-3-r}{2} k_{B} T⟨H1​⟩=26n−3−r​kB​T

The corresponding heat capacities,

CV=(6n−3−r)2kB, and CP=CV+kB=(6n−1−r)2kBC_{V}=\frac{(6 n-3-r)}{2} k_{B}, \quad \text { and } \quad C_{P}=C_{V}+k_{B}=\frac{(6 n-1-r)}{2} k_{B}CV​=2(6n−3−r)​kB​, and CP​=CV​+kB​=2(6n−1−r)​kB​

are temperature independent. The ratio γ=CP/CV\gamma=C_{P} / C_{V}γ=CP​/CV​ is easily measured in adiabatic processes. Values of γ\gammaγ, expected on the basis of the above argument, are listed below for a number of different molecules.

Monatomic

n=4n=4n=4

Measurements of the heat capacity of dilute gases do not agree with the above predictions. For example, the value CV/kB=7/2C_{V} / k_{B}=7 / 2CV​/kB​=7/2, for a diatomic gas such as oxygen, is only observed at temperatures higher than a few thousand degrees Kelvin. At room temperatures, a lower value of 5/25 / 25/2 is observed, while at even lower temperatures of around 100K10^{0} K100K, it is further reduced to 3/2.3 / 2 .3/2. The low temperature value is similar to that of a monatomic gas, and suggests that no energy is stored in the rotational and vibrational degrees of freedom. These observations can be explained if the allowed energy levels are quantized.

  • Vibrational modes: A diatomic molecule has one vibrational mode with stiffness K≡mω2K \equiv m \omega^{2}K≡mω2, where ω\omegaω is the frequency of oscillations. The classical partition function for this mode is
Zvibc=∫dpdqhexp⁡[−β(p22m+mω2q22)]=1h(2πmβ)(2πβmω2)=2πhβω=kBTℏω\begin{aligned} Z_{\mathrm{vib}}^{c} &=\int \frac{d p d q}{h} \exp \left[-\beta\left(\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{m \omega^{2} q^{2}}{2}\right)\right] \\ &=\frac{1}{h} \sqrt{\left(\frac{2 \pi m}{\beta}\right)\left(\frac{2 \pi}{\beta m \omega^{2}}\right)}=\frac{2 \pi}{h \beta \omega}=\frac{k_{B} T}{\hbar \omega} \end{aligned}Zvibc​​=∫hdpdq​exp[−β(2mp2​+2mω2q2​)]=h1​(β2πm​)(βmω22π​)​=hβω2π​=ℏωkB​T​​

where ℏ=h/2π\hbar=h / 2 \piℏ=h/2π. The corresponding energy stored in this mode,

⟨Hvib⟩c=−∂ln⁡Z∂β=∂ln⁡(βℏω)∂β=1β=kBT\left\langle\mathcal{H}_{\mathrm{vib}}\right\rangle^{c}=-\frac{\partial \ln Z}{\partial \beta}=\frac{\partial \ln (\beta \hbar \omega)}{\partial \beta}=\frac{1}{\beta}=k_{B} T⟨Hvib​⟩c=−∂β∂lnZ​=∂β∂ln(βℏω)​=β1​=kB​T

comes from kBT/2k_{B} T / 2kB​T/2 per kinetic and potential degrees of freedom. In quantum mechanics, the allowed values of energy are quantized such that

Hvibq=ℏω(n+12)\mathcal{H}_{\mathrm{vib}}^{q}=\hbar \omega\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right)Hvibq​=ℏω(n+21​)

with n=0,1,2,⋯n=0,1,2, \cdotsn=0,1,2,⋯. Assuming that the probability of each discrete level is proportional to its Boltzmann weight (as will be justified later on), there is a normalization factor

Zvibq=∑n=0∞e−βℏω(n+1/2)=e−βℏω/21−e−βℏωZ_{\mathrm{vib}}^{q}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} e^{-\beta \hbar \omega(n+1 / 2)}=\frac{e^{-\beta \hbar \omega / 2}}{1-e^{-\beta \hbar \omega}}Zvibq​=n=0∑∞​e−βℏω(n+1/2)=1−e−βℏωe−βℏω/2​

The high temperature limit,

lim⁡β→0Zvibq=1βℏω=kBTℏω\lim _{\beta \rightarrow 0} Z_{\mathrm{vib}}^{q}=\frac{1}{\beta \hbar \omega}=\frac{k_{B} T}{\hbar \omega}β→0lim​Zvibq​=βℏω1​=ℏωkB​T​

coincides with eq.(VI.8)(due in part to the choice of hhh as the measure of classical phase space).

The expectation value of vibrational energy is

Evibq=−∂ln⁡Z∂β=ℏω2+∂∂βln⁡(1−e−βℏω)=ℏω2+ℏωe−βℏω1−e−βℏωE_{\mathrm{vib}}^{q}=-\frac{\partial \ln Z}{\partial \beta}=\frac{\hbar \omega}{2}+\frac{\partial}{\partial \beta} \ln \left(1-e^{-\beta \hbar \omega}\right)=\frac{\hbar \omega}{2}+\hbar \omega \frac{e^{-\beta \hbar \omega}}{1-e^{-\beta \hbar \omega}}Evibq​=−∂β∂lnZ​=2ℏω​+∂β∂​ln(1−e−βℏω)=2ℏω​+ℏω1−e−βℏωe−βℏω​

The first term is the energy cost of quantum fluctuations that are present even in the zero temperature ground state. The second term describes the additional energy due to thermal fluctuations. The resulting heat capacity,

Cvibq=dEvibqdT=kB(ℏωkBT)2e−βℏω(1−e−βℏω)2C_{\mathrm{vib}}^{q}=\frac{d E_{\mathrm{vib}}^{q}}{d T}=k_{B}\left(\frac{\hbar \omega}{k_{B} T}\right)^{2} \frac{e^{-\beta \hbar \omega}}{\left(1-e^{-\beta \hbar \omega}\right)^{2}}Cvibq​=dTdEvibq​​=kB​(kB​Tℏω​)2(1−e−βℏω)2e−βℏω​

achieves the classical value of kBk_{B}kB​ only at temperatures T≫θvibT \gg \theta_{\mathrm{vib}}T≫θvib​, where θvib=ℏω/kB\theta_{\mathrm{vib}}=\hbar \omega / k_{B}θvib​=ℏω/kB​ is a characteristic temperature associated with the quanta of vibrational energy. For T≪θvib T \ll \theta_{\text {vib }}T≪θvib ​, Cvib qC_{\text {vib }}^{q}Cvib q​ goes to zero as exp⁡(−θvib /T)\exp \left(-\theta_{\text {vib }} / T\right)exp(−θvib ​/T). Typical values of θvib \theta_{\text {vib }}θvib ​ are in the range of 10310^{3}103 to 10410^{4}104 degrees Kelvin, explaining why the classical value of heat capacity is observed only at higher temperatures.

  • Rotational modes: To account for the low temperature anomaly in the heat capacity of diatomic molecules, we have to study the quantization of the rotational degrees of freedom. Classically, the orientation of a diatomic molecule is specified by two angles θ\thetaθ and ϕ\phiϕ, and its Lagrangian (equal to the kinetic energy) is
L=I2(θ˙2+sin⁡2θϕ˙2)\mathcal{L}=\frac{I}{2}\left(\dot{\theta}^{2}+\sin ^{2} \theta \dot{\phi}^{2}\right)L=2I​(θ˙2+sin2θϕ˙​2)

where III is the moment of inertia. In terms of the conjugate momenta,

pθ=∂Ldθ˙=Iθ˙,pϕ=∂Ldϕ˙=Isin⁡2θϕ˙p_{\theta}=\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{d \dot{\theta}}=I \dot{\theta}, \quad p_{\phi}=\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{d \dot{\phi}}=I \sin ^{2} \theta \dot{\phi}pθ​=dθ˙∂L​=Iθ˙,pϕ​=dϕ˙​∂L​=Isin2θϕ˙​

the Hamiltonian for rotations is

Hrot=12I(pθ2+pϕ2sin⁡2θ)≡L⃗22I\mathcal{H}_{\mathrm{rot}}=\frac{1}{2 I}\left(p_{\theta}^{2}+\frac{p_{\phi}^{2}}{\sin ^{2} \theta}\right) \equiv \frac{\vec{L}^{2}}{2 I}Hrot​=2I1​(pθ2​+sin2θpϕ2​​)≡2IL2​

where L⃗\vec{L}L is the angular momentum. From the classical partition function,

Zrot c=1h2∫0πdθ∫02πdϕ∫−∞∞dpθdpϕexp⁡[−β2I(pθ2+pϕ2sin⁡2θ)]=(2πIβ)(4πh2)=2IkBTℏ2\begin{aligned} Z_{\text {rot }}^{c} &=\frac{1}{h^{2}} \int_{0}^{\pi} d \theta \int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \phi \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} d p_{\theta} d p_{\phi} \exp \left[-\frac{\beta}{2 I}\left(p_{\theta}^{2}+\frac{p_{\phi}^{2}}{\sin ^{2} \theta}\right)\right] \\ &=\left(\frac{2 \pi I}{\beta}\right)\left(\frac{4 \pi}{h^{2}}\right)=\frac{2 I k_{B} T}{\hbar^{2}} \end{aligned}Zrot c​​=h21​∫0π​dθ∫02π​dϕ∫−∞∞​dpθ​dpϕ​exp[−2Iβ​(pθ2​+sin2θpϕ2​​)]=(β2πI​)(h24π​)=ℏ22IkB​T​​

the stored energy is

⟨Erot⟩c=−∂ln⁡Z∂β=∂∂βln⁡(βℏ22I)=kBT\left\langle E_{\mathrm{rot}}\right\rangle^{c}=-\frac{\partial \ln Z}{\partial \beta}=\frac{\partial}{\partial \beta} \ln \left(\frac{\beta \hbar^{2}}{2 I}\right)=k_{B} T⟨Erot​⟩c=−∂β∂lnZ​=∂β∂​ln(2Iβℏ2​)=kB​T

as expected for two degrees of freedom. In quantum mechanics, the allowed values of angular momentum are quantized to L⃗2=ℏ2ℓ(ℓ+1)\vec{L}^{2}=\hbar^{2} \ell(\ell+1)L2=ℏ2ℓ(ℓ+1) with ℓ=0,1,2,⋯\ell=0,1,2, \cdotsℓ=0,1,2,⋯, and each state has a degeneracy of 2ℓ+12 \ell+12ℓ+1 (along a selected direction, Lz=−ℓ,⋯ ,+ℓ).\left.L_{z}=-\ell, \cdots,+\ell\right) .Lz​=−ℓ,⋯,+ℓ). A partition function is now obtained for these levels as

Zrot q=∑ℓ=0∞exp⁡[−βℏ2ℓ(ℓ+1)2I](2ℓ+1)=∑ℓ=0∞exp⁡[−θrot ℓ(ℓ+1)T](2ℓ+1)Z_{\text {rot }}^{q}=\sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\frac{\beta \hbar^{2} \ell(\ell+1)}{2 I}\right](2 \ell+1)=\sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty} \exp \left[-\frac{\theta_{\text {rot }} \ell(\ell+1)}{T}\right](2 \ell+1)Zrot q​=ℓ=0∑∞​exp[−2Iβℏ2ℓ(ℓ+1)​](2ℓ+1)=ℓ=0∑∞​exp[−Tθrot ​ℓ(ℓ+1)​](2ℓ+1)

where θrot =ℏ2/(2IkB)\theta_{\text {rot }}=\hbar^{2} /\left(2 I k_{B}\right)θrot ​=ℏ2/(2IkB​) is a characteristic temperature associated with quanta of rotational energy. While the sum can not be analytically evaluated in general, we can study its high and low temperature limits:

(a) For T≫θrot T \gg \theta_{\text {rot }}T≫θrot ​, the terms in eq.(VI.19) vary slowly, and the sum can be replaced by the integral

lim⁡T→∞Zrot q=∫0∞dx(2x+1)exp⁡[−θrot x(x+1)T]=∫0∞dye−θrot y/T=Tθrot =Zrot c\begin{aligned} \lim _{T \rightarrow \infty} Z_{\text {rot }}^{q} &=\int_{0}^{\infty} d x(2 x+1) \exp \left[-\frac{\theta_{\text {rot }} x(x+1)}{T}\right] \\ &=\int_{0}^{\infty} d y e^{-\theta_{\text {rot } y / T}}=\frac{T}{\theta_{\text {rot }}}=Z_{\text {rot }}^{c} \end{aligned}T→∞lim​Zrot q​​=∫0∞​dx(2x+1)exp[−Tθrot ​x(x+1)​]=∫0∞​dye−θrot y/T​=θrot ​T​=Zrot c​​

i.e. the classical result of eq.(VI.17) is recovered.

(b) For T≪θrot T \ll \theta_{\text {rot }}T≪θrot ​, the first few terms dominate the sum, and

lim⁡T→∞Zrotq=1+3e−2θrot/T+O(e−6θrot/T)\lim _{T \rightarrow \infty} Z_{\mathrm{rot}}^{q}=1+3 e^{-2 \theta_{\mathrm{rot}} / T}+\mathcal{O}\left(e^{-6 \theta_{\mathrm{rot}} / T}\right)T→∞lim​Zrotq​=1+3e−2θrot​/T+O(e−6θrot​/T)

leading to an energy

Erotq=−∂ln⁡Z∂β≈−∂∂βln⁡[1+3e−2θrot/T]≈6kBθrote−2θrot/TE_{\mathrm{rot}}^{q}=-\frac{\partial \ln Z}{\partial \beta} \approx-\frac{\partial}{\partial \beta} \ln \left[1+3 e^{-2 \theta_{\mathrm{rot}} / T}\right] \approx 6 k_{B} \theta_{\mathrm{rot}} e^{-2 \theta_{\mathrm{rot}} / T}Erotq​=−∂β∂lnZ​≈−∂β∂​ln[1+3e−2θrot​/T]≈6kB​θrot​e−2θrot​/T

The resulting heat capacity vanishes at low temperatures as

Crot=dErotqdT=3kB(2θrotT)2e−2θrot/T+⋯C_{\mathrm{rot}}=\frac{d E_{\mathrm{rot}}^{q}}{d T}=3 k_{B}\left(\frac{2 \theta_{\mathrm{rot}}}{T}\right)^{2} e^{-2 \theta_{\mathrm{rot}} / T}+\cdotsCrot​=dTdErotq​​=3kB​(T2θrot​​)2e−2θrot​/T+⋯

Typical values of θrot \theta_{\text {rot }}θrot ​ are between 1 and 10∘K10^{\circ} K10∘K, explaining the lower temperature shoulder in the heat capacity measurements. At very low temperatures, the only contributions come from the kinetic energy of the center of mass, and the molecule behaves as a monatomic particle. (The heat capacity vanishes at even lower temperatures due to quantum statistics, as will be discussed in the context of identical particles.)

\section{VI.B Vibrations of a Solid}

Attractive interactions between particles first lead to condensation from a gas to liquid at low temperatures, and finally cause freezing into a solid state at even lower temperatures. For the purpose of discussing its thermodynamics, the solid can be regarded as a very large molecule subject to a Hamiltonian similar to eq.(VI.1), with n=N≫1n=N \gg 1n=N≫1 atoms. We can then proceed with the steps outlined in the previous section.

(a) The classical ground state configuration of the solid is obtained by minimizing the potential V\mathcal{V}V. In almost all cases, the minimum energy corresponds to a periodic arrangement of atoms forming a lattice. In terms of the three basis vectors, a^,b^\hat{a}, \hat{b}a^,b^, and c^\hat{c}c^, the locations of atoms in a simple crystal are given by

q⃗∗(ℓ,m,n)=[ℓa^+mb^+nc^]≡r⃗\vec{q}^{*}(\ell, m, n)=[\ell \hat{a}+m \hat{b}+n \hat{c}] \equiv \vec{r}q​∗(ℓ,m,n)=[ℓa^+mb^+nc^]≡r

where {ℓ,m,n}\{\ell, m, n\}{ℓ,m,n} is a triplet of integers.

(b) At finite temperatures, the atoms may undergo small deformations

q⃗r⃗=r⃗+u⃗(r⃗)\vec{q}_{\vec{r}}=\vec{r}+\vec{u}(\vec{r})q​r​=r+u(r)

with a cost in potential energy of

V=V∗+12∑r⃗,r⃗′α,β∂2V∂qr⃗,α∂qr⃗′,βuα(r⃗)uβ(r⃗′)+O(u3)\mathcal{V}=\mathcal{V}^{*}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\vec{r}, \vec{r}^{\prime} \atop \alpha, \beta} \frac{\partial^{2} \mathcal{V}}{\partial q_{\vec{r}, \alpha} \partial q_{\vec{r}^{\prime}, \beta}} u_{\alpha}(\vec{r}) u_{\beta}\left(\vec{r}^{\prime}\right)+O\left(u^{3}\right)V=V∗+21​α,βr,r′​∑​∂qr,α​∂qr′,β​∂2V​uα​(r)uβ​(r′)+O(u3)

(c) Finding the normal modes of a crystal is considerably simplified by its translational symmetry. In particular, the matrix of second derivatives only depends on the relative separation of two points,

∂2V∂qr⃗,α∂qr⃗′,β=Kαβ(r⃗−r⃗′)\frac{\partial^{2} \mathcal{V}}{\partial q_{\vec{r}, \alpha} \partial q_{\vec{r}^{\prime}, \beta}}=K_{\alpha \beta}\left(\vec{r}-\vec{r}^{\prime}\right)∂qr,α​∂qr′,β​∂2V​=Kαβ​(r−r′)

It is always possible to take advantage of such a symmetry to at least partially diagonalize the matrix by using a Fourier basis,

uα(r⃗)=∑k⃗′eik⃗⋅r⃗Nu~α(k⃗)u_{\alpha}(\vec{r})=\sum_{\vec{k}}^{\prime} \frac{e^{i \vec{k} \cdot \vec{r}}}{\sqrt{N}} \tilde{u}_{\alpha}(\vec{k})uα​(r)=k∑′​N​eik⋅r​u~α​(k)

The sum is restricted to wavevectors k⃗\vec{k}k inside a Brillouin zone. For example, in a cubic lattice of spacing aaa, each component of k⃗\vec{k}k is restricted to the interval [−π/a,π/a][-\pi / a, \pi / a][−π/a,π/a] This is because wavevectors outside this interval carry no additional information as (kx+2πm/a)(na)=kx(na)+2mnπ\left(k_{x}+2 \pi m / a\right)(n a)=k_{x}(n a)+2 m n \pi(kx​+2πm/a)(na)=kx​(na)+2mnπ, and any phase that is a multiple of 2π2 \pi2π does not effect the sum in eq.(VI.28). In terms of the Fourier modes, the potential energy of deformations is

\mathcal{V}=\mathcal{V}^{*}+\frac{1}{2 N} \sum_{\left(\vec{r}, \vec{r}^{\prime}\right),\left(\vec{k}, \vec{k}^{\prime}\right)}_{\alpha, \beta} K_{\alpha \beta}\left(\vec{r}-\vec{r}^{\prime}\right) e^{i \vec{k} \cdot \vec{r}} \tilde{u}_{\alpha}(\vec{k}) e^{i \vec{k}^{\prime} \cdot \vec{r}^{\prime}} \tilde{u}_{\beta}\left(\vec{k}^{\prime}\right)

by setting

In a classical treatment, each harmonic oscillator of non-zero stiffness contributes kBTk_{B} TkB​T to the internal energy of the solid. At most, 6 of the 3N3 N3N oscillators are expected to have zero stiffness (corresponding to uniform translations and rotations of the crystal). Thus, up to non-extensive corrections of order 1/N1 / N1/N, the classical internal energy associated with Hamiltonian (VI.33) is 3NkBT3 N k_{B} T3NkB​T, leading to a temperature independent heat capacity of 3kB3 k_{B}3kB​ per atom. In fact, the measured heat capacity vanishes at low temperatures. We can again relate this observation to the quantization of the energy levels of each oscillator, as discussed in the previous section. Quantizing each harmonic mode separately, gives the allowed values of the Hamiltonian as

As a first attempt at including quantum mechanical effects, we may adopt the Einstein model in which all the oscillators are assumed to have the same frequency ωE.\omega_{E} .ωE​. This model corresponds to atoms that are pinned to their ideal location by springs of stiffness Kˉ=∂2V/∂q2=mωE2.\bar{K}=\partial^{2} \mathcal{V} / \partial q^{2}=m \omega_{E}^{2} .Kˉ=∂2V/∂q2=mωE2​. The resulting internal energy,

E=E0+3NℏωEe−βℏωE1−e−βℏωEE=E_{0}+3 N \frac{\hbar \omega_{E} e^{-\beta \hbar \omega_{E}}}{1-e^{-\beta \hbar \omega_{E}}}E=E0​+3N1−e−βℏωE​ℏωE​e−βℏωE​​

C=dEdT=3NkB(TET)2e−TE/T(1−e−TE/T)2C=\frac{d E}{d T}=3 N k_{B}\left(\frac{T_{E}}{T}\right)^{2} \frac{e^{-T_{E} / T}}{\left(1-e^{-T_{E} / T}\right)^{2}}C=dTdE​=3NkB​(TTE​​)2(1−e−TE​/T)2e−TE​/T​

is simply proportional to that of a single oscillator (eqs.(VI.12) and (VI.13)). In particular, there is an exponential decay of the heat capacity to zero with a characteristic temperature TE=ℏωE/kB.T_{E}=\hbar \omega_{E} / k_{B} .TE​=ℏωE​/kB​. However, the experimentally measured heat capacity decays to zero much more slowly, as T3T^{3}T3

The discrepancy is resolved through the Debye model, which emphasizes that at low temperatures the main contribution to heat capacity is from the oscillators of lowest frequency that are the most easily excited. The lowest energy modes in turn correspond to smallest wavevectors k=∣k⃗∣k=|\vec{k}|k=∣k∣, or longest wavelengths λ=2π/k.\lambda=2 \pi / k .λ=2π/k. Indeed, the modes with k⃗=0\vec{k}=0k=0 simply describe pure translations of the lattice and have zero stiffness. By continuity we expect, lim⁡k⃗→0K~(k⃗)=0\lim _{\vec{k} \rightarrow 0} \tilde{K}(\vec{k})=0limk→0​K~(k)=0, and ignoring considerations of crystal symmetry, the expansion of K~(k⃗)\tilde{K}(\vec{k})K~(k) at small wavevectors takes the form

K~(k⃗)=Bk2+O(k4)\tilde{K}(\vec{k})=B k^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(k^{4}\right)K~(k)=Bk2+O(k4)

The odd terms are absent in the expansion, since K~(k⃗)=K~(−k⃗)\tilde{K}(\vec{k})=\tilde{K}(-\vec{k})K~(k)=K~(−k) follows from K(r⃗−r⃗′)=K\left(\vec{r}-\vec{r}^{\prime}\right)=K(r−r′)= K(r⃗′−r⃗)K\left(\vec{r}^{\prime}-\vec{r}\right)K(r′−r) in real space. The corresponding frequencies at long wavelengths are

ω(k⃗)=Bk2m=vk\omega(\vec{k})=\sqrt{\frac{B k^{2}}{m}}=v kω(k)=mBk2​​=vk

where v=B/mv=\sqrt{B / m}v=B/m​ is the speed of sound in the crystal. (In a real material, K~αβ\tilde{K}_{\alpha \beta}K~αβ​ is not proportional to δαβ\delta_{\alpha \beta}δαβ​, and different polarizations of sound have different velocities.)

The quanta of vibrational modes are usually referred to as phonons. Using the dispersion relation in eq.(VI.40), the contribution of phonons to the internal energy is

⟨Hq⟩=E0+∑k⃗,αℏvkeβℏvk−1\left\langle\mathcal{H}^{q}\right\rangle=E_{0}+\sum_{\vec{k}, \alpha} \frac{\hbar v k}{e^{\beta \hbar v k}-1}⟨Hq⟩=E0​+k,α∑​eβℏvk−1ℏvk​

With periodic boundary conditions in a box of dimensions Lx×Ly×LzL_{x} \times L_{y} \times L_{z}Lx​×Ly​×Lz​, the allowed wavevectors are

k⃗=(2πnxLx,2πnyLy,2πnzLz)\vec{k}=\left(\frac{2 \pi n_{x}}{L_{x}}, \frac{2 \pi n_{y}}{L_{y}}, \frac{2 \pi n_{z}}{L_{z}}\right)k=(Lx​2πnx​​,Ly​2πny​​,Lz​2πnz​​)

where nx,nyn_{x}, n_{y}nx​,ny​, and nzn_{z}nz​ are integers. In the large size limit, these modes are very densely packed, and the number of modes in a volume element d3k⃗d^{3} \vec{k}d3k is

dN=dkx2π/Lxdky2π/Lydkx2π/Lz=V(2π)3d3k⃗≡ρd3k⃗d \mathcal{N}=\frac{d k_{x}}{2 \pi / L_{x}} \frac{d k_{y}}{2 \pi / L_{y}} \frac{d k_{x}}{2 \pi / L_{z}}=\frac{V}{(2 \pi)^{3}} d^{3} \vec{k} \equiv \rho d^{3} \vec{k}dN=2π/Lx​dkx​​2π/Ly​dky​​2π/Lz​dkx​​=(2π)3V​d3k≡ρd3k

Using the phase space density ρ\rhoρ, any sum over allowed wavevectors can be replaced by an integral as

lim⁡V→∞∑k⃗f(k⃗)=∫d3k⃗ρf(k⃗)\lim _{V \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{\vec{k}} f(\vec{k})=\int d^{3} \vec{k} \rho f(\vec{k})V→∞lim​k∑​f(k)=∫d3kρf(k)

Hence, eq.(VI.41) can be re-written as

E=E0+3V∫B.Zd3k⃗(2π)3ℏvkeβℏvk−1E=E_{0}+3 V \int^{B . Z} \quad \frac{d^{3} \vec{k}}{(2 \pi)^{3}} \frac{\hbar v k}{e^{\beta \hbar v k}-1}E=E0​+3V∫B.Z(2π)3d3k​eβℏvk−1ℏvk​

where the integral is performed over the volume of the Brillouin zone, and the factor of 3 comes from assuming the same sound velocity for the three polarizations.

Due to its dependence on the shape of the Brillouin zone, it is not possible to give a simple closed form expression for the energy in eq.(VI.45). However, we can examine its high and low temperature limits. The characteristic temperature separating the two limits,

TD=ℏvkmax⁡kB≈ℏvkB⋅πaT_{D}=\frac{\hbar v k_{\max }}{k_{B}} \approx \frac{\hbar v}{k_{B}} \cdot \frac{\pi}{a}TD​=kB​ℏvkmax​​≈kB​ℏv​⋅aπ​

corresponds to the high frequency modes at the edge of the zone. For T≫TDT \gg T_{D}T≫TD​, all modes behave classically. The integrand of eq.(VI.45) is just kBTk_{B} TkB​T, and since the total number of modes is 3N=3V∫B.Z. d3k⃗/(2π)33 N=3 V \int^{\text {B.Z. }} d^{3} \vec{k} /(2 \pi)^{3}3N=3V∫B.Z. d3k/(2π)3, the classical results of E(T)=E0+3NkBTE(T)=E_{0}+3 N k_{B} TE(T)=E0​+3NkB​T, and C=3NkBC=3 N k_{B}C=3NkB​ are recovered. For T≪TDT \ll T_{D}T≪TD​, the factor exp⁡(βℏvk)\exp (\beta \hbar v k)exp(βℏvk) in the denominator of eq.(VI.45) is very large at the Brillouin zone edge. The most important contribution to the integral comes from small kkk, and the error in extending the integration range to infinity is small. After changing variables to x=βℏv∣k⃗∣x=\beta \hbar v|\vec{k}|x=βℏv∣k∣, and using d3k⃗=4πx2dx/(βℏv)3d^{3} \vec{k}=4 \pi x^{2} d x /(\beta \hbar v)^{3}d3k=4πx2dx/(βℏv)3 due to spherical symmetry, eq.(VI.45) gives

lim⁡T≪TDE(T)≈E0+3V8π3(kBTℏv)34πkBT∫0∞dxx3ex−1=E0+π210V(kTℏv)3kBT\begin{aligned} \lim _{T \ll T_{D}} E(T) & \approx E_{0}+\frac{3 V}{8 \pi^{3}}\left(\frac{k_{B} T}{\hbar v}\right)^{3} 4 \pi k_{B} T \int_{0}^{\infty} d x \frac{x^{3}}{e^{x}-1} \\ &=E_{0}+\frac{\pi^{2}}{10} V\left(\frac{k T}{\hbar v}\right)^{3} k_{B} T \end{aligned}T≪TD​lim​E(T)​≈E0​+8π33V​(ℏvkB​T​)34πkB​T∫0∞​dxex−1x3​=E0​+10π2​V(ℏvkT​)3kB​T​

(The value of the definite integral, π4/15≈6.5\pi^{4} / 15 \approx 6.5π4/15≈6.5, can be found in standard tables.) The resulting heat capacity,

C=dEdT=kBV2π25(kBTℏv)3C=\frac{d E}{d T}=k_{B} V \frac{2 \pi^{2}}{5}\left(\frac{k_{B} T}{\hbar v}\right)^{3}C=dTdE​=kB​V52π2​(ℏvkB​T​)3

has the form C∝NkB(T/TD)3C \propto N k_{B}\left(T / T_{D}\right)^{3}C∝NkB​(T/TD​)3 in agreement with observations. The physical interpretation of this result is the following: At temperatures T≪TDT \ll T_{D}T≪TD​, only a fraction of the phonon modes can be thermally excited. These are the low frequency phonons with energy quanta ℏω(k⃗)≪kBT.\hbar \omega(\vec{k}) \ll k_{B} T .ℏω(k)≪kB​T. The excited phonons have wavevectors ∣k⃗∣<k∗(T)≈(kBT/ℏv)|\vec{k}|<k^{*}(T) \approx\left(k_{B} T / \hbar v\right)∣k∣<k∗(T)≈(kB​T/ℏv) Quite generally, in ddd space dimensions, the number of these modes is approximately Vk∗(T)d∼V(kBT/ℏv)d.V k^{*}(T)^{d} \sim V\left(k_{B} T / \hbar v\right)^{d} .Vk∗(T)d∼V(kB​T/ℏv)d. Each excited mode can be treated classically, and contributes roughly kBTk_{B} TkB​T to the internal energy which thus scales as E∼V(kBT/ℏv)dkBT.E \sim V\left(k_{B} T / \hbar v\right)^{d} k_{B} T .E∼V(kB​T/ℏv)dkB​T. The corresponding heat capacity, C∼VkB(kBT/ℏv)dC \sim V k_{B}\left(k_{B} T / \hbar v\right)^{d}C∼VkB​(kB​T/ℏv)d, vanishes as TdT^{d}Td.

\section{VI.C Black-body Radiation}

Phonons correspond to vibrations of a solid medium. There are also (longitudinal) sound modes in liquid and gas states. However, even "empty" vacuum, can support fluctuations of the electromagnetic (EM) field, photons, which can be thermally excited at finite temperatures. The normal modes of this field are EM waves, characterized by a wave-number k⃗\vec{k}k, and two possible polarizations α.\alpha .α. (Since ∇⋅E⃗=0\nabla \cdot \vec{E}=0∇⋅E=0 in free space, the electric field must be normal to k⃗\vec{k}k, and only transverse modes exist.) With appropriate choice of coordinates, the Hamiltonian for the EM field can be written as a sum of harmonic oscillators,

H=12∑k⃗,α[∣p~k⃗,α∣2+ωα(k⃗)2∣u~α(k⃗)∣2]\mathcal{H}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\vec{k}, \alpha}\left[\left|\tilde{p}_{\vec{k}, \alpha}\right|^{2}+\omega_{\alpha}(\vec{k})^{2}\left|\tilde{u}_{\alpha}(\vec{k})\right|^{2}\right]H=21​k,α∑​[∣∣∣∣​p~​k,α​∣∣∣∣​2+ωα​(k)2∣∣∣∣​u~α​(k)∣∣∣∣​2]

with ωα(k⃗)=ck\omega_{\alpha}(\vec{k})=c kωα​(k)=ck, where ccc is the speed of light.

With periodic boundary conditions, the allowed wavevectors in a box of size LLL are k⃗=2π(nx,ny,nz)/L\vec{k}=2 \pi\left(n_{x}, n_{y}, n_{z}\right) / Lk=2π(nx​,ny​,nz​)/L where {nx,ny,nz}\left\{n_{x}, n_{y}, n_{z}\right\}{nx​,ny​,nz​} are integers. However, unlike phonons, there is no Brillouin zone limiting the size of k⃗\vec{k}k, and these integers can be arbitrarily large. The lack of such a restriction leads to the ultraviolet catastrophe in a classical treatment: As there is no limit to the wavevector, assigning kBTk_{B} TkB​T per mode leads to an infinite energy stored in the high frequency modes. (The low frequencies are cut off by the finite size of the box.) It was indeed to resolve this difficulty that Planck suggested that the allowed values of EM energy must be quantized according to the Hamiltonian

Hq=∑k⃗,αℏck(nα(k⃗)+12), with nα(k⃗)=0,1,2,⋯\mathcal{H}^{q}=\sum_{\vec{k}, \alpha} \hbar c k\left(n_{\alpha}(\vec{k})+\frac{1}{2}\right), \quad \text { with } \quad n_{\alpha}(\vec{k})=0,1,2, \cdotsHq=k,α∑​ℏck(nα​(k)+21​), with nα​(k)=0,1,2,⋯

As for phonons, the internal energy is calculated from

E=⟨Hq⟩=∑k⃗,αℏck(12+e−βℏck1−e−βℏck)=VE0+2V(2π)3∫d3k⃗ℏckeβℏck−1E=\left\langle\mathcal{H}^{q}\right\rangle=\sum_{\vec{k}, \alpha} \hbar c k\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{e^{-\beta \hbar c k}}{1-e^{-\beta \hbar c k}}\right)=V E_{0}+\frac{2 V}{(2 \pi)^{3}} \int d^{3} \vec{k} \frac{\hbar c k}{e^{\beta \hbar c k}-1}E=⟨Hq⟩=k,α∑​ℏck(21​+1−e−βℏcke−βℏck​)=VE0​+(2π)32V​∫d3keβℏck−1ℏck​

The zero-point energy is actually infinite, but as only energy differences are measured, it is usually ignored. The change of variables to x=βℏckx=\beta \hbar c kx=βℏck allows us to calculate the excitation energy,

E∗V=ℏcπ2(kBTℏc)4∫0∞dxxex−1=π215(kBTℏc)3kBT\begin{aligned} \frac{E^{*}}{V} &=\frac{\hbar c}{\pi^{2}}\left(\frac{k_{B} T}{\hbar c}\right)^{4} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{d x x}{e^{x}-1} \\ &=\frac{\pi^{2}}{15}\left(\frac{k_{B} T}{\hbar c}\right)^{3} k_{B} T \end{aligned}VE∗​​=π2ℏc​(ℏckB​T​)4∫0∞​ex−1dxx​=15π2​(ℏckB​T​)3kB​T​

The EM radiation also exerts a pressure on the walls of the container. From the partition function of the Hamiltonian (VI.50),

Z=∑{nα(k⃗)}exp⁡[−βℏω(k⃗)(nα(k⃗)+12)]=∏k⃗,αe−βℏck/21−e−βℏckZ=\sum_{\left\{n_{\alpha}(\vec{k})\right\}} \exp \left[-\beta \hbar \omega(\vec{k})\left(n_{\alpha}(\vec{k})+\frac{1}{2}\right)\right]=\prod_{\vec{k}, \alpha} \frac{e^{-\beta \hbar c k / 2}}{1-e^{-\beta \hbar c k}}Z={nα​(k)}∑​exp[−βℏω(k)(nα​(k)+21​)]=k,α∏​1−e−βℏcke−βℏck/2​

the free energy is

F=−kBTln⁡Z=kBT∑k⃗,α[βℏck2+ln⁡(1−e−βℏck)]=2V∫d3k⃗(2π)3[ℏck2+kBTln⁡(1−e−βℏck)]\begin{aligned} F &=-k_{B} T \ln Z=k_{B} T \sum_{\vec{k}, \alpha}\left[\frac{\beta \hbar c k}{2}+\ln \left(1-e^{-\beta \hbar c k}\right)\right] \\ &=2 V \int \frac{d^{3} \vec{k}}{(2 \pi)^{3}}\left[\frac{\hbar c k}{2}+k_{B} T \ln \left(1-e^{-\beta \hbar c k}\right)\right] \end{aligned}F​=−kB​TlnZ=kB​Tk,α∑​[2βℏck​+ln(1−e−βℏck)]=2V∫(2π)3d3k​[2ℏck​+kB​Tln(1−e−βℏck)]​

The pressure due to the photon gas is

P=−∂F∂V∣T=−∫d3k⃗(2π)3[ℏck+2kBTln⁡(1−e−βℏck)]=P0−kBTπ2∫0∞dkk2ln⁡(1−e−βℏck) (integrate by parts) =P0+kBTπ2∫0∞dkk33βℏce−βℏck1−e−βℏck( compare with eq.(VI.51)) =P0+13EV\begin{aligned} P &=-\left.\frac{\partial F}{\partial V}\right|_{T}=-\int \frac{d^{3} \vec{k}}{(2 \pi)^{3}}\left[\hbar c k+2 k_{B} T \ln \left(1-e^{-\beta \hbar c k}\right)\right] \\ &=P_{0}-\frac{k_{B} T}{\pi^{2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} d k k^{2} \ln \left(1-e^{-\beta \hbar c k}\right) \quad \text { (integrate by parts) } \\ &=P_{0}+\frac{k_{B} T}{\pi^{2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} d k \frac{k^{3}}{3} \frac{\beta \hbar c e^{-\beta \hbar c k}}{1-e^{-\beta \hbar c k}} \quad(\text { compare with eq.(VI.51)) }\\ &=P_{0}+\frac{1}{3} \frac{E}{V} \end{aligned}P​=−∂V∂F​∣∣∣∣∣​T​=−∫(2π)3d3k​[ℏck+2kB​Tln(1−e−βℏck)]=P0​−π2kB​T​∫0∞​dkk2ln(1−e−βℏck) (integrate by parts) =P0​+π2kB​T​∫0∞​dk3k3​1−e−βℏckβℏce−βℏck​( compare with eq.(VI.51)) =P0​+31​VE​​

Note that there is also an infinite zero-point pressure P0.P_{0} .P0​. Differences in this pressure lead to the Casimir force between conducting plates, which is measurable.

The extra pressure of 1/31 / 31/3 times the energy density can be compared to that of a gas of relativistic particles. (As shown in the test problems, a dispersion relation, E∝∣p⃗∣s\mathcal{E} \propto|\vec{p}|^{s}E∝∣p​∣s, leads to a pressure, P=(s/d)(E/V)P=(s / d)(E / V)P=(s/d)(E/V) in ddd dimensions.) Continuing with the analogy to a gas of particles, if a hole is opened in the container wall, the escaping energy flux per unit area and per unit time is

ϕ=⟨c⊥⟩EV\phi=\left\langle c_{\perp}\right\rangle \frac{E}{V}ϕ=⟨c⊥​⟩VE​

All photons have speed ccc, and the average of the component of the velocity perpendicular to the hole can be calculated as

⟨c⊥⟩=c×14π∫0π/22πsin⁡θdθcos⁡θ=c4\left\langle c_{\perp}\right\rangle=c \times \frac{1}{4 \pi} \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} 2 \pi \sin \theta d \theta \cos \theta=\frac{c}{4}⟨c⊥​⟩=c×4π1​∫0π/2​2πsinθdθcosθ=4c​

resulting in

ϕ=14cEV=π260kB4T4ℏ3c2\phi=\frac{1}{4} c \frac{E}{V}=\frac{\pi^{2}}{60} \frac{k_{B}^{4} T^{4}}{\hbar^{3} c^{2}}ϕ=41​cVE​=60π2​ℏ3c2kB4​T4​

The result, ϕ=σT4\phi=\sigma T^{4}ϕ=σT4, is the Stephan-Boltzmann law for blackbody radiation, and

σ=π260kB4ℏ3c2≈5.67×10−8Wm−2∘K−4\sigma=\frac{\pi^{2}}{60} \frac{k_{B}^{4}}{\hbar^{3} c^{2}} \approx 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{Wm}^{-2 \circ} \mathrm{K}^{-4}σ=60π2​ℏ3c2kB4​​≈5.67×10−8Wm−2∘K−4

is Stephan's constant. Blackbody radiation has a characteristic frequency dependence: Let E(T)/V=∫dkE(k,t)E(T) / V=\int d k \mathcal{E}(k, t)E(T)/V=∫dkE(k,t), where

E(k,T)=ℏcπ2k3eβℏck−1\mathcal{E}(k, T)=\frac{\hbar c}{\pi^{2}} \frac{k^{3}}{e^{\beta \hbar c k}-1}E(k,T)=π2ℏc​eβℏck−1k3​

is the energy density in wavevector kkk. The flux of emitted radiation in the interval [k,k+dk][k, k+d k][k,k+dk] is I(k,T)dkI(k, T) d kI(k,T)dk, where

I(k,T)=c4E(k,T)=ℏc24π2k3eβℏck−1→{ckBTk2/4π for k≪k∗(T)ℏc2k3e−βℏck/4π2 for k≫k∗(T)I(k, T)=\frac{c}{4} \mathcal{E}(k, T)=\frac{\hbar c^{2}}{4 \pi^{2}} \frac{k^{3}}{e^{\beta \hbar c k}-1} \rightarrow \begin{cases}c k_{B} T k^{2} / 4 \pi & \text { for } k \ll k^{*}(T) \\ \hbar c^{2} k^{3} e^{-\beta \hbar c k} / 4 \pi^{2} & \text { for } k \gg k^{*}(T)\end{cases}I(k,T)=4c​E(k,T)=4π2ℏc2​eβℏck−1k3​→{ckB​Tk2/4πℏc2k3e−βℏck/4π2​ for k≪k∗(T) for k≫k∗(T)​

The characteristic wavevector k∗(T)≈kBT/ℏck^{*}(T) \approx k_{B} T / \hbar ck∗(T)≈kB​T/ℏc separates quantum and classical regimes. It provides the upper cutoff that eliminates the ultraviolet catastrophe. MIT OpenCourseWare
